bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, February 9, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 62. Consular. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia Feb'y 9, 1901
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.

p.add: See letters to Mr of June 1 1900

div1.p: Subject. The A. M. Miller Estate.
Synopsis. The Liberian Government has decided that I must obtain the Certificates of credit from the Hon., F. O. Thorn, and present them to the Government for pay matter.

p.add: Dec 22 from Littlefield See 73--June 4/01 form Monrovia.

div1.p: No. 62. Consular Legation of the United States. Monrovia Liberia; Feb'y 9, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say, that since writing my No. 61, Consular of Feb'y 7, 1901, I have record a note, Feby 8, 1901, from the State Department, Monrovia; informing me that the Cabinet had decided that I must obtain the Government certificates of credit from the Hon. F. O. Thorn, the senior Senator for Maryland County Liberia, (inasmuch as the depositing them with him by Miss Winifred Miller, through Hon. W. H. Heard, my

my predecessor, for collection, was a personal and private agreement between them; of which the Government has no control) and that upon the presentation of the said Government certifactes of credit, by me, the Government will do its best in trying to pay the said amount, in such money as (will) may be available.
I have this day made a formal request upon the Hon. Mr. Thorn, for the immediate return of the said Government Certificates of credit to me.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
